author: @paulpanashemunatsi6714
text: Hello lm doing this but l cant print any data at the end this my code so far   import sqlite3 import json from datetime import datetime  timeframe  = '2015-01' sql_transaction = [ ]  connection  = sqlite3.connect('{}.db'.format(timeframe)) c = connection.cursor()  def create_table():     c.execute(""" CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS parent_reply (parent_id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,comment_id TEXT UNIQUE, parent TEXT ,comment TEXT,subreddit TEXT,unix INT,score INT )""")  def format_data(data):     data = data.replace("\n"," newlinechar ").replace("\r","newlinechar").replace(' " '," ' ")     return data  def find_parent(pid):     try:             sql = "SELECT comment FROM parent_reply WHERE comment_id = '{}' LIMIT 1 ".format(pid)             c.excute(sql)             result = c.fetchone()             if result != None:                 return result[0]             else: return False          except Exception as e:         #print("find_parent",e)         return False      if __name__ == "__main__":         create_table()         row_counter = 0         paired_rows = 0        with open("C:/chatdata/reddit_data/{}/RC_{}".format(timeframe.split('-')[0],timeframe), buffering= 1000) as f:         for row in f:             print(row)             row_counter += 1             row = json.loads(row)             parent_id = row['parent_id']             body = format_data(row['body'])             created_uct = row['created_utc']             score = row['score']             subreddit = row['subreddit']             parent_data = find_parent(parent_id)

author: @sayyamjain1607
text: with open('J:/chatdata/reddit_data/{}/RC_{}'.format(timeframe.split('-')[0],timeframe), buffering=1000) as f:  {} means string provided at specific position timeframe = '2015-05' So, timeframe.split('-') means first {} will recieve String "2015" as [0] index is mentioned. , and second {} will receive timeframe as ,timeframe is mentioned so together String becomes:  'J:/chatdata/reddit_data/2015/RC_2015-05'

author: @FalcoGer
text: python is so ugly if something return string else return boolean wtf dude? a = 5 if random condition:   a = random_function_that_sometimes_returns_a_string_instead_of_an_int() a = a + 3 congratulations. you just made a lovely mess that crashes sometimes, giving you a lovely time tracking down bugs that shouldn't be possible to write in the first place. ever heard of typing? it's that useful thing where the compiler makes sure you can't do bullshit operations, because you randomly assigned a completely different datatype to a variable in some random execution path that you didn't account for. and suddenly you have True + "Hello world." and the compiler won't say a thing until you hit that brick wall because no typing. in normal languages that implement typing it's hard enough to deal with null, but now you can assign any data type to any variable in python just makes it a nightmare. you can't even ask your ide what you can do with the variable because there is no way to know what type a variable might be at any given time.

Not just the methods, if's, for's, functions etc. But, how to think properly. Watching you makes me feel confident and reminds me of how much fun and creativity can be born through the power of programming.   Another thing I have always appreciated about you is your dedication to creating videos of high quality and you are not afraid to tackle some of the most complex aspects of programming.
